title: Myxedema Coma Diagnostic Score
description: Diagnostic scoring system for myxedema coma (MC), a rare but life-threatening decompensated state of extreme hypothyroidism. This validated scoring system facilitates early recognition and treatment by evaluating thermoregulatory, central nervous, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and metabolic dysfunction along with precipitating events.

parameters.name: body_temperature
parameters.description: Core body temperature reflecting thermoregulatory dysfunction in severe hypothyroidism

parameters.name: central_nervous_system
parameters.description: Central nervous system manifestations of severe hypothyroidism affecting consciousness and neurological function

parameters.name: cardiovascular_dysfunction
parameters.description: Cardiovascular manifestations including heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac function abnormalities

scoring.moderate_bradycardia_hypotension: Moderate bradycardia (HR <60 bpm) or hypotension (10 points)

parameters.name: gastrointestinal_dysfunction
parameters.description: Gastrointestinal manifestations including constipation, ileus, and motility disorders

scoring.moderate_distension: Moderate abdominal distension, decreased bowel sounds (10 points)
scoring.severe_ileus: Severe ileus, absent bowel sounds (15 points)

parameters.name: metabolic_dysfunction
parameters.description: Metabolic abnormalities including hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, and other electrolyte disturbances

scoring.severe_hyponatremia_hypoglycemia: Severe hyponatremia (Na+ <120 mEq/L) or hypoglycemia (15 points)

parameters.name: precipitating_event
parameters.description: Presence of precipitating events that may trigger myxedema coma in patients with severe hypothyroidism

scoring.minor_stress: Minor stress (medication changes, mild illness) (5 points)
scoring.major_stress: Major stress (severe infection, major surgery, trauma) (15 points)

result.name: myxedema_coma_score
result.description: Total diagnostic score for myxedema coma with corresponding diagnostic probability assessment

ranges.interpretation: Score <25 makes the diagnosis of myxedema coma unlikely. Consider alternative diagnoses for altered mental status and hypothermia.
Low probability of myxedema coma. Continue evaluation for other causes while considering thyroid function assessment.

ranges.description: Patient at risk for myxedema coma
ranges.interpretation: Intermediate probability - patient at risk for myxedema coma. Urgent thyroid function testing and close monitoring recommended.
High probability - potentially diagnostic for myxedema coma. Immediate emergency treatment with IV levothyroxine and supportive care indicated.

references: Popoveniuc G, Chandra T, Sud A, Sharma M, Blackman MR, Burman KD, et al. A diagnostic scoring system for myxedema coma. Endocr Pract. 2014;20(8):808-17. doi: 10.4158/EP13460.OR.
Mathew V, Misgar RA, Ghosh S, Mukhopadhyay P, Roychowdhury P, Pandit K, et al. Myxedema coma: a new look into an old crisis. J Thyroid Res. 2011;2011:493462. doi: 10.4061/2011/493462.
Wall CR. Myxedema coma: diagnosis and treatment. Am Fam Physician. 2000;62(11):2485-90.
formula: Myxedema Coma Score = Body Temperature Points + Central Nervous System Points + Cardiovascular Points + Gastrointestinal Points + Metabolic Points + Precipitating Event Points
notes: Myxedema coma is a rare but life-threatening decompensated state of extreme hypothyroidism with mortality rates of 25-50%
The scoring system has 100% sensitivity and 85.71% specificity at a cutoff score of 60
Area under the ROC curve is 0.88 (95% CI: 0.65 to 1.00), indicating excellent diagnostic performance
Score ≥60 is potentially diagnostic for myxedema coma and requires immediate treatment
Scores 45-59 classify patients at risk and warrant urgent thyroid function testing
Score <25 makes myxedema coma unlikely, though severe hypothyroidism may still be present
Common precipitating events include infection, surgery, trauma, medications (sedatives, narcotics), cold exposure
Temperature measurement should be core temperature; skin temperature may be misleadingly normal
Early recognition and treatment are critical as delayed treatment significantly increases mortality
Treatment includes IV levothyroxine, supportive care, and management of precipitating factors
The scoring system should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and thyroid function tests
